text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Civil servants intending to stand for the general election scheduled for later this year are advised by President Daniel arap Moi to resign and start their campaigns.

- Kenya is expected to lead other wildlife-rich nations against a proposal to lift an eight-year ban on ivory trading at the Convention on International Trade in endangered species beginning on Monday in Harare.
- The Nairobi City Council is set to lose millions of shillings if the Local Government minister approves a suspect tender award recommended by a council officer.
- The head of the Roman Catholic Church in Kenya, Archbishop Ndingi Mwana a'Nzeki, says Kenyans need constitutional reforms but should not resort to violence.
- Michael Kijana Wamalwa, the official opposition leader, says Kenyan opposition leaders have failed to agree on a single presidential candidate.
- President Moi slams the opposition for trying to smuggle into Kenya controversial Islamic street preacher Sheikh Ahmed Balala.

- Opposition parliamentarian Paul Muite calls on opposition supporters to prepare for the invasion and forceful occupation of Parliament on June 19 to derail the 1997/98 budget speech, in an effort to force the government into dialogue.
- President Moi defies opposition leaders who claimed they would make the country ungovernable by July to effect the threat and meet the full force of the law.

- Ugandan officials say they were nonplussed by President Moi's claim that a Ugandan minister and the head of Ugandan intelligence were invited to Kenya by a Kenyan non-governmental organisation last week.
- The Uganda government gains ground in its battle over pay with striking MPs.
- Nine foreign companies express interest in a privatised power sector in Tanzania.
